lexUnit.name: feel.v
lexUnit.definition: COD: have a belief or impression, especially without an identifiable reason.

sentence.text: I feel that if you do not continue to love then you will die in some way .
Some members will feel that the Institute , instead of regulating them , ought to have protected them from regulation .
He felt that human beings were all manifestations of a divine purpose .
Because I feel strongly that I am much more than that … perhaps many more nameless things , but valuable to me nonetheless .
He felt sure Ari was not convinced by such blatant lies .
I felt sure that he would be absolutely your cup of tea .
Some of them feel they have been by-passed in the new security structure that is being set up with American advice ; American officers are present at most police briefings .
I feel I am making progress .
I feel I should wash all the rocks again but I fear the problem will return .
I felt these elementary slips should be corrected , and came up with a possible solution .
Not surprisingly , the court does not feel it necessary to disturb the decision with regard to either appellant .
Simply , the need for delegation arises where one person feels it appropriate to ask a subordinate to carry out tasks which he or she would normally do .
She already felt that she was learning something about art .
I still feel that the situation brought about by the local BDA group was an unnecessary waste of valuable hospital resources .
They felt that clear national guide-lines would perhaps help .
I 've always felt that was a somewhat surprising sidelight . "
She comments that people seemed to feel that child care was an appropriate service for kin to perform for each other , but also that they should not be exploited .
